qc.notes: Image set is complete and of good quality. Some minor specular glare is present on the forehead and cheeks but does not significantly impede analysis. A large nose ring occludes a portion of the right nasal ala in some views.

skin_type.label: combination
skin_type.rationale: Your T-zone, particularly the forehead and nose, shows a mild, stable gloss across different angles, suggesting some oil production. In contrast, your cheeks (U-zone) appear more matte with minimal shine. This difference between an oilier T-zone and balanced-to-dry cheeks is characteristic of combination skin.

skin_tone_fitzpatrick.label: III
skin_tone_fitzpatrick.note: Based on skin color and features, your skin is likely to tan with minimal burning.

skin_age_range.rationale: The assessment is based on the presence of very mild superficial static lines on the forehead, with excellent firmness and minimal signs of photoaging in other areas.

analysis.overview_explanation: Your skin analysis indicates a combination skin type, with the most notable concerns being moderate under-eye darkening and mild, uneven pigmentation on the cheeks. You also have some visible pores, primarily concentrated in the T-zone. Overall, your skin shows minimal signs of redness, acne, or significant textural issues.

pores.rationale_plain: Your pores are mildly prominent, with the highest visibility and density on your nose and the medial parts of your cheeks, which is typical for a T-zone presentation. Pores on your forehead and chin are much less conspicuous, and they are minimal on the outer cheeks.
possible_causes: Pore size is largely determined by genetics.
Higher oil (sebum) production in the T-zone can make pores in that area appear more prominent.
The accumulation of dead skin cells and debris can stretch pores, making them look larger.

identified_subtypes.explanation: The visibility of your pores is clearly concentrated in the central T-zone (forehead, nose, and chin), with the nose showing the most prominence. The pores on the U-zone (cheeks) are significantly smaller and less dense.
likely_causes: The T-zone naturally has a higher concentration of sebaceous (oil) glands compared to other areas of the face.
Increased sebum production in this area can cause pores to appear enlarged.
This pattern is classic for combination and oily skin types.
care_education: Regular cleansing helps to remove excess oil and debris that can accumulate in pores.
Using products containing ingredients that help exfoliate within the pore lining can improve their appearance.
While you cannot change the genetic size of your pores, keeping them clear can make them appear smaller.

wrinkles.rationale_plain: Your skin shows very minimal signs of static wrinkles. There are a few faint, superficial horizontal lines visible on the forehead, but no significant lines are apparent at rest around the eyes (crow's feet) or mouth. The chin-up view shows good skin integrity in the neck area.
possible_causes: Fine lines on the forehead often begin as dynamic lines from repeated facial expressions, such as raising the eyebrows.
Over time, with collagen loss and sun exposure, these can become etched into the skin and remain visible at rest.
Dehydration can make fine lines appear more pronounced.

identified_subtypes.explanation: The faint horizontal lines on your forehead are present even when your facial muscles are relaxed. This indicates they are static lines, though they are currently very superficial.
likely_causes: These are likely the early evolution of dynamic expression lines into static ones due to intrinsic aging.
Chronic sun exposure accelerates the breakdown of collagen and elastin, which helps to set these lines into the skin.
Skin hydration levels can also affect the visibility of fine lines.
care_education: Consistent sun protection is the most important step to prevent the worsening of existing lines and the formation of new ones.
Keeping your skin well-hydrated with moisturizers can help to plump the skin and make fine lines appear less obvious.
Ingredients that support the skin's collagen production can be beneficial for improving the appearance of fine lines over the long term.

pigmentation.rationale_plain: Your overall skin tone is quite even, but there are scattered, low-contrast darker macules (spots) visible on the cheeks. Additionally, the under-eye area contributes to the overall pigmentation score. There are no large, confluent patches of discoloration visible.
possible_causes: Sun exposure is a primary driver for the development of localized hyperpigmentation like sun spots.
Past inflammation, such as from minor skin injuries or breakouts, can also leave behind darker marks known as post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation (PIH).
Genetic predisposition can influence how skin responds to sun and inflammation.

identified_subtypes.explanation: You have a few small, discrete, and slightly darkened spots on the cheeks. These are consistent in appearance with solar lentigines, commonly known as sun spots or age spots.
likely_causes: These spots are a direct result of cumulative exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from the sun over many years.
Individuals with lighter skin tones (like Fitzpatrick III) are more susceptible to developing sun spots.
Your location in New Delhi suggests high levels of ambient UV radiation, which increases the likelihood of sun damage.
care_education: The most effective step is diligent, daily use of a high-SPF, broad-spectrum sunscreen to prevent new spots from forming and existing ones from darkening.
Incorporating ingredients known for their brightening properties into your skincare routine can help lessen the appearance of these spots.
Regular, gentle exfoliation can help to gradually fade the appearance of superficial pigmentation.

citations.title: Skin Pigmentation Types, Causes and Treatment—A Review (PMC)

pigmentation.uncertainty_notes: The distinction between small sun spots and post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation can be difficult from images alone.

redness.rationale_plain: There are no signs of significant or persistent facial redness. Your skin tone appears very uniform and calm across all regions. There may be a trace of redness around the nasal alae (nostrils), but it is minimal.
possible_causes: Minimal redness around the nostrils can be common and may be related to minor irritation from wiping or blowing the nose.
Your skin does not show indications of sensitivity or inflammatory conditions that typically cause redness.
For most individuals, a complete absence of redness is rare, and your skin shows a very low level of visible erythema.

texture.rationale_plain: Your skin texture is generally smooth and even across most of your face. A mild degree of unevenness is noted in the T-zone, which corresponds to the areas with more prominent pores. There are no signs of coarse texture, cross-hatching, or significant flaking.
possible_causes: Uneven texture is often related to a buildup of dead skin cells on the surface.
Enlarged pores can also contribute to a less-uniform micro-relief.
Dehydration can sometimes accentuate textural irregularities.

identified_subtypes.explanation: The texture appears uneven primarily on the nose and medial cheeks, where pores are more visible. The rest of the face, such as the forehead and outer cheeks, has a smoother appearance.
likely_causes: The visible openings of pores naturally create a departure from a perfectly smooth surface.
A slightly slowed rate of natural skin cell turnover can lead to minor build-up, contributing to a look of unevenness.
Environmental factors, like pollution, can also play a role in surface irregularities.
care_education: Gentle and regular exfoliation is a key step to promote the shedding of dead skin cells for a smoother surface.
Maintaining good hydration helps to keep the skin's surface plump and can improve the appearance of texture.
Ensuring your skin is properly cleansed each day removes surface debris that can contribute to a rougher feel.

acne.rationale_plain: The images show no evidence of active acne lesions, such as comedones (blackheads or whiteheads), papules, or pustules. Your skin appears very clear in this regard.
possible_causes: A lack of visible acne suggests that factors that typically contribute to breakouts—such as excess oil, clogged pores, bacteria, and inflammation—are currently well-balanced.
Effective cleansing and skincare habits can prevent the formation of acne lesions.
Hormonal fluctuations are a common trigger for acne, and their absence may contribute to clear skin.

under_eye.rationale_plain: There is a noticeable and well-defined area of darkening under both eyes, creating a moderate contrast with the upper cheek skin. This appears to be caused by a combination of factors, including pigmentation and the natural structure of the under-eye area creating a slight shadow. The left and right sides are largely symmetrical.
possible_causes: Genetics often play a significant role in the prominence of under-eye circles.
Thin skin in this area can make underlying blood vessels more visible, and sun exposure can increase pigmentation.
Lifestyle factors like lack of sleep or allergies can also contribute.

identified_subtypes.explanation: The under-eye area has a visible brownish tint, which suggests an excess of melanin (pigment) in the skin. This is a common contributor to dark circles.
likely_causes: Chronic sun exposure without adequate protection can stimulate melanin production in this delicate area.
There is often a strong genetic predisposition to developing pigmentary dark circles.
Post-inflammatory changes from rubbing the eyes due to allergies or habits can also lead to darkening.
care_education: Consistent daily use of a broad-spectrum sunscreen is crucial to prevent further darkening from UV exposure.
Look for eye creams with ingredients that can help brighten the appearance of skin over time.
Being gentle with the eye area and avoiding rubbing can help prevent irritation that may worsen pigmentation.

identified_subtypes.explanation: The natural contour of your bone structure creates a subtle indentation or "tear trough" under the eyes. This hollow can catch shadows, making the area appear darker than it is.
likely_causes: The shape of the skull and the underlying fat pads are determined by genetics and are a primary cause of structural shadowing.
Age-related volume loss in the cheeks and under-eye area can accentuate the hollow over time.
Dehydration can temporarily make these hollows appear more pronounced.
care_education: While topical products cannot change bone structure, keeping the skin well-hydrated may help to slightly plump the skin surface.
Certain cosmetic ingredients can help support skin structure and improve its overall appearance.
Advanced options for addressing significant volume loss are available through dermatologists.

citations.title: Validated photonumeric scale for infraorbital dark circles (PMC)

under_eye.uncertainty_notes: The relative contributions of pigment, vascularity, and structure to under-eye circles can be difficult to determine precisely from 2D images alone.

limitations: This is a non-diagnostic analysis based on visual RGB cues from smartphone photos and is not a substitute for professional medical advice.
Lighting variations and camera quality can affect results; analysis is based on the images as provided.
Skin type assessment is based on visual proxies for oil and dryness, which may not capture underlying hydration status.
